Comment: Rachel Maddow just reported on a situation that happened in Oklahoma where 20 armed men claiming to be with ICE, FBI and Homeland Security, with jackets featuring those organizations, stormed a residence. At home? A woman and her two young girls. Windows were smashed, the door broken down, and the women were held at gunpoint. They were US citizens who just moved from Maryland to Oklahoma. The husband was expecting to arrive in a few days. The armed men took their phones, confiscated all electronics, took their cash, tore apart every single room "looking" for evidence. Meanwhile, the mother cried out and pleaded with them that they are citizens and that the men need to tell them what's going on, what this is all about. They claimed they were illegal immigrants. But she showed ID's proving their citizenship. They were forced outside, dressed in underwear, into the rainy night and watched in horror as the house was ransacked. After the assault ended? The men left. With all of the things they'd confiscated, including cash. The mother pleaded for identification and a way to contact them. They were given NOTHING.  The local news reported the story. The ICE denied involvement. FBI said they were involved in a supportive capacity at first, then later switched to denying involvement. Homeland Security is not responsive, just ignoring inquiries.

Comment: Yes, but keep the other elements in mind:  >There are many statutory exceptions to the Posse Comitatus Act, but the most important one is the Insurrection Act. Under this law, in response to a state government’s request, the president may deploy the military to suppress an insurrection in that state. In addition, the Insurrection Act allows the president — with or without the state government’s consent — to use the military to enforce federal law or suppress a rebellion against federal authority in a state, or to protect a group of people’s civil rights when the state government is unable or unwilling to do so.  https://www.brennancenter.org/our-work/research-reports/posse-comitatus-act-explained

[https://www.propublica.org/article/inside-secret-ap3-militia-american-patriots-three-percent](https://www.propublica.org/article/inside-secret-ap3-militia-american-patriots-three-percent)  [https://www.wired.com/story/extremist-militias-are-coordinating-on-facebook/](https://www.wired.com/story/extremist-militias-are-coordinating-on-facebook/)  [https://web.archive.org/web/20250417224109/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/11/us/politics/far-right-militias-border-trump.html](https://web.archive.org/web/20250417224109/https://www.nytimes.com/2024/12/11/us/politics/far-right-militias-border-trump.html)  Some will almost certainly take the opportunity to come out from the shadows anyway, claiming they are "protecting our communities", and "helping local and federal law enforcement". You have already seen the right wing marching openly, although masked, in the streets in some places.  [https://truthout.org/articles/we-are-back-proud-boys-march-in-dc-celebrating-trumps-inauguration/](https://truthout.org/articles/we-are-back-proud-boys-march-in-dc-celebrating-trumps-inauguration/)  I think there will be violence, it is unavoidable, it will just be the scale that is hard to judge at the moment. I would never condone any form of violence, but I do not think it will be the average American that will start it.
